main_pages.title: Context (May 1st)
main_pages.description: On May 1, 1970 a group of approximately 500 students gathered at the Victory Bell to protest President Nixon’s announcement of the Cambodian Incursion the night before.  After burying a copy of Constituation as a symbol of an unjust expansion of an already unpopular war, they called for a larger, more organized protest at noon on Monday, May 4, 1970.
After a weekend of turmoil off campus and on, an estimated 2000 people, gathered that Monday to protest the Vietnam War and the presence of the Ohio National Guard on campus

main_pages.title: Commemoration
main_pages.description: Since 1971, friends, family, and students gather in silence at the Victory Bell at 11:00 pm on May 3 for the start of the annual Candlelight Vigil and March. On May 4, the bell is rung 15 times-- once for each of the victims of the Kent State shooting and the two men killed at Jackson State.

main_pages.title: Voices for Change
main_pages.description: Why did students protest in 1970?  Should students protest today? What gives Americans the right to protest?

content_items.item_description: A growing crowd gathers at the Victory Bell, May 4, 1970.
Trails of light from the first annual Candlelight March and Vigil, May 3, 1971.
Oral History with Catherine Delattre.
President Nixon's Cambodia Incursion Address.

main_pages.title: Context (May 2nd)
main_pages.description: On May 2, 1970, approximately 600 students gathered at the ROTC building with the intent to burn it down. During the Vietnam War,197 ROTC buildings around the country were targeted as a form of protest. After the crowd disrupted the Fire Department's attempt to put out the blaze, the police arrived to disperse the crowd and the National Guard was called on to escort the fireman.  When the students left, the fire appeared under control. There is still controversy over who started the final blaze -- students or agents provocateurs.

On the morning of May 4, 1970, approximately 100 guardsmen stood watch in front of the remains of the burned ROTC building. Just past noon, they split into two groups to disperse the protestors gathered on the Commons.

main_pages.title: Commemoration
main_pages.description: During the annual Candlelight March and Vigil on the night of May 3, marchers walk past the area where the ROTC building once stood.

main_pages.title: Voices for Change
main_pages.description: Does violence generate more violence?  Is destruction of property ever an acceptable form of protest? Did the descruction of the ROTC building warrent the Guard's response?

content_items.item_description: Front of ROTC remains, 5/3, 11:00 AM.
Crowd gathers near ROTC remains, 5/3, 11:30-noon.
Personal Statement by Leslie Wasson after the burning of the ROTC Building.
Video of ROTC burning (May 2 1970).

main_pages.title: Context (May 1st)
main_pages.description: The Pagoda was created shortly before May 4, 1970 as a classroom project by five architecture students.
At 12:24 pm, 28 guardsmen turned directly in front of the Pagoda and fired 67 shots into the Prentice Hall Parking Lot.

main_pages.title: Commemoration
main_pages.description: Many people visit the Pagoda to understand and remember the events of May 4, 1970.

main_pages.title: Voices for Change
main_pages.description: Are there limits to the First Amendment? Should the government be allowed to quell dissent? Was the use of deadly force justified?

content_items.item_description: A view of National Guard around the time of the shooting.
Oral History with Naomi Goelman Etzkin.
First Amendment to the United States Constitution.

main_pages.title: Context (May 1st)
main_pages.description: Prior to the shootings, the Prentice Hall Parking was like many of the parking lots on campus -- unremarkable.

Jeffery Miller, Allison Krause, William Schreoder, and Sandy Scheuer were killed in the Prentice Parking Lot. In 1971, the B'nai B'rith/Faculty Marker was erected in their honor.  In 1999, markers were added to identify the spots where they fell.

main_pages.title: Commemoration
main_pages.description: In 1971, the B'nai B'rith Hillel/Faculty Marker was erected in their honor and in 1999, markers were placed in the parking spots where they fell. Every year, volunteers silently stand vigil inside each marker from midnight May 4 until the start of the commemoration program at noon.

main_pages.title: Voices for Change
main_pages.description: Why are rituals and memorials important? What are some ways you can honor the fallen? Why do you think it took so long for the university to create markers for the fallen students?

content_items.item_description: The first official May 4 memorial, the B'nai B'rith Hillel/Faculty marker, 1977.
Dean Kahler, a wounded students, holds a candle where Jeffery Miller died during the Candlelight Vigil, 1977.
Dedication ceremony for the Parking Lot Markers, 1999.
The May 4 shootings at Kent State Unversity: The search for historical accuracy.

main_pages.title: Context (May 1st)
main_pages.description: Don Drumm, an acclaimed sculptor and Kent State alum, created Solar Totem #1 in 1967 out of corten steel designed to weather over time.
One of the 67 shots fired by the National Guard pierced the Solar Totem.  Two students, John Cleary and Joe Lewis, were injured nearby.

main_pages.title: Commemoration
main_pages.description: The University asked Don Drumm to repair the bullet hole, but he refused.  Every year on May 3, visitors decorate the sculpture with chalked messages of peace and rememberance.

main_pages.title: Voices for Change
main_pages.description: Should Don Drumm have repaired Solar Totem #1? How has the meaning of the sculpture changed over time?  Is Solar Totem #1 a memorial?

content_items.item_description: Bullet hole in tree by Don Drumm sculpture.
Reflections on May 4: Don Drumm.
Artist Don Drumm reflects on his sculpture’s role in May 4.

main_pages.title: Context (May 1st)
main_pages.description: The Gym Annex did not exist in 1970.  Its construction inspired a major protest over the preservation of the May 4 site.
While most guardsman fired in the direction of the Prentice Hall Parking Lot, one guardsman turned and fired his shotgun at Jim Russell in the area that is now covered by the Gym Annex.

main_pages.title: Commemoration
main_pages.description: In 1977, protesters pitched tents and created a community known as Tent City on the proposed construction site.  After months of demonstrations and negiotiations, 193 individuals -- including the parents of Sandy Scheuer and members of the Canfora family -- were arrested for their role in obstructing the construction.  Even today, there are still calls to "Tear Down the Gym."

main_pages.title: Voices for Change
main_pages.description: What is the role of place in memory? Did the construction of the Gym Annex hurt the memory of May 4? Did the University act responsibly?

content_items.item_description: Students from schools across the nation gathered in support of the Tent City.
A view of Tent City.
An aerial view of Gym Annex contruction site.
Oral History with Barry Seybert.
Tent City / Gym Annex Protest Chronology.

main_pages.title: Context (May 1st)
main_pages.description: The May 4 Memorial was dedicated in 1990, after a controversial design competition.
The site for the Memorial was selected in part because it overlooks the Commons, the site of many of the events of May 1 - 4, 1970.

main_pages.title: Commemoration
main_pages.description: After a national competition where the original winner was disqualified, Architect Bruno Ast's second place design was selected and built at much smaller scale than he initially proposed. Today, the Memorial serves as a place to silently reflect on the legacy of meaning of May 4, 1970.

main_pages.title: Voices for Change
main_pages.description: Do you think the Memorial is an appropriate tribute to the fallen and wounded students? How can you best "learn, inquire" and "reflect" on the legacy of May 4, 1970? Should Kent State complete the Memorial?

content_items.item_description: A view of the hill before the Memorial.
